predicted_summary: Amends the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States to: (1) make no change to the tariff schedule on or before 6/ 30/99; and (2) require the Secretary of the Treasury, through the President, to provide for the elimination of specified duties and surcharges on the import and export of specified amounts of specified products.
summary: Amends the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States to suspend, through June 30, 1999, the duty on certain drug substances used as HIV antiviral drugs:  (1) (S)-N-tert-butyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydro- 3-isoquinoline carboxamide; (2) (S)-N-tert-butyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydro-3- isoquinoline carboxamide hydrochloride salt; (3) (S)-N-tert-butyl- 1,2,3,4- tetrahydro-3-isoquinoline carboxamide sulfate salt; and (4) (3S)-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline-3-carboxylic acid.

predicted_summary: Directs the Secretary of Education to award grants to local educational agencies that serve an elementary or secondary school in which: (1) a majority of students are from families with incomes below the poverty line; and (2) the students are receiving computer software for multilingual education.Directs the Secretary of Education to conduct an annual study of the effectiveness of this grant program.Amends the Community Services Block Grant Act to require the Secretary of Education to provide financial assistance only to an elementary or secondary school in which a majority of students are from families with incomes below the poverty line, as defined by the Office of Management and Budget and in effect under this Act.4) Directs the Secretaries of Information Technology and Multilingual Education to: (1) make grants to eligible partnerships to pay the federal share of the cost of establishing and carrying out such programs; and (2) seek a partnership's approval to seek a grant to provide additional information technology training and multilingual education programs.Requires the Secretary to make grants to local educational agencies to assist such agencies in awarding bonuses to teachers who achieve information technology certification.Requires the Secretary to establish criteria that require a student to obtain both technological and multilingual education.Information Technology Certification Act of 1998 - Amends the Employment Standards Act of 1965 to authorize the Secretary of Education, after consultation with the computing technology industry association or the information technology training association, to certify certified computer programmers, systems analysts, and computer scientists or engineers (as such occupations are defined by the Bureau of Labor Statistics), to issue licenses to teachers who meet specified standards.Requires the Secretary of Education to act jointly with the Secretary to ensure the safety and well-being of all students.
summary: Multilingual Education and Technological Advancement Act of 2001 - Authorizes the Secretary of Education to make competitive grants to local educational agencies (LEAs) to provide financial assistance to elementary and secondary schools for obtaining: (1) computer software for multilingual education, with preference given to schools with a majority of students from poor families or a high concentration of students with low levels of English proficiency; and (2) computers, with grant awards mandatory for schools where a majority of students meet poverty criteria or where there are a specified low number of computers for students.Authorizes the Secretary, jointly with the Secretary of Labor, to make matching grants for: (1) information technology training programs for former participants in such programs who have not received information technology certification, minorities, women, older individuals, veterans, Native Americans, and dislocated workers; and (2) multilingual education programs. Requires a partnership, to be eligible for such a grant, to consist of: (1) an institution of higher education; and (2) a private organization, such as a certified commercial information technology training provider or an information technology trade or professional association.Authorizes the Secretary to make grants to LEAs to assist them in awarding bonuses to teachers who achieve information technology certification.Authorizes the Secretary to make competitive grants to institutions of higher education to provide scholarships to students who: (1) are preparing to enter the teaching profession; and (2) meet criteria established by the Secretary that requires them to obtain both technological and multilingual education.

predicted_summary: The United States has experienced record trade deficits that have made the United States the largest debt debtor in the world.Balanced Trade Certificate - Directs the holder of the certificate with a license to import into the United States a good amount of merchandise, and to provide the holder with a good deal of value-added tax credit.The Secretary, in cooperation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, shall promulgate regulations for the issuance of certificates to exporters and valuing certificates from importers.Certificates of Exports - The value of a certificate is equal to a multiple of the appraised value of the good exported.Directs the Secretary of Homeland Security to establish a system for the collection of certificates submitted by importers to the Secretary.The aggregate face value of the certificate required to import the oil or gas is equal to, or greater than, the appraised value of such oil and gas imported pursuant to this Act.Directs the Secretary of Homeland Security (DHS) to permanently remove a certificate from circulation to ensure the transferability and validity of such certificates.
summary: Balanced Trade Restoration Act of 2006 - Directs the Secretary of Commerce to establish a Balanced Trade Certificate Program within the International Trade Administration of the Department of Commerce. Provides under such Program for the issuance of certificates to measure and control U.S. imports and exports to achieve a balance in the foreign trade of the United States. Exempts importers of oil or gas during the first five years of the program.

predicted_summary: Imports by or for the benefit of a manufacturer of men's and boys' shirts under the terms of U.S. Code ยง 9902.52.09 woven fabrics of free no change no change on or before 12/12/12 cotton of a type 31/2008 described in this Act.Amends the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States to: (1) limit the aggregate quantity of fabrics entered under such a schedule to 85% of the total squarefoot of a manufacturer's business; and (2) allow manufacturers to enter into agreements with the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) without the approval of the Secretary of Agriculture or the Commerce Department.Directs the Secretary of Commerce to issue licenses to eligible cotton woven fabrics manufacturers to import cotton fabrics.3) The date of purchase shall be the invoice date if the manufacturer is not the importer of record; and the date of entry if the Manufacturer is the importers of record.Directs the Secretary to transfer to the Trust Fund, from the General Fund of the Treasury, amounts determined to be equivalent to the amounts received in the Fund that are attributable to duties received since January 1, 1994.Directs the funds to be directed to: (1) yarn spinners of pima cotton grown in the United States who qualify under this Act; and (2) ring spun cotton spinning spinner of the same size, measuring less than 83.33 decitex (exceeding 120 metric number) for all spinners who qualify.The affidavit required by this Act affirms: (1) that the manufacturer used imported cotton fabric during the period January 1, 1998, through February 1, 2003, to cut and sew men's and boys' woven cotton shirts.Directs the Attorney to file an affidavit certifying the use of pima cotton grown in the United States and the dollar value of imported woven cotton shirting fabric.Provides that the producer maintains supporting documentation showing the quantity of ring spun cotton yarns produced, and evidencing the yarns as ring spun yarns, which are subject to appeal or protest.
summary:
Amends the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States (HTSUS) to reduce, through December 31, 2008 , the duty on certain cotton shirting fabrics.

Limits the quantity of imported cotton woven fabric entered by or on behalf of each manufacturer of men's and boy's shirts. Provides for the issuance of import licenses subject to such limitation.

Establishes the Pima Cotton Trust Fund within the Treasury, consisting of transfers from the general fund in amounts attributable to the duty received since January 1, 1994, on woven fabrics of cotten under specified HTSUS headings.

Provides for annual distribution of amounts from such Fund to a nationally recognized association of shirting manufacturers for the promotion of U.S.-grown pima cotton, and to yarn spinners of such cotton.

predicted_summary: Provides that a covered entity may deny employment opportunities to a job applicant or employee if it: (1) is based on the need of the covered entity to make reasonable accommodations to the known limitations related to the pregnancy, childbirth, or related medical conditions of an employee; or (2) is concerned that such accommodation would impose an undue hardship on the operation of such entity.Revises the powers, procedures, and remedies this Act provides to the Commission, the Attorney General, or any person alleging a violation of title vii of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.Provides that the powers, remedies, and procedures this Act provides to the Board of Directors alleging an unlawful employment practice in violation of this Act against an employee described in subparagraph (Sec. 3)Requires the Secretary of the Treasury to report to Congress on a practice that: (1) violates the powers, remedies, and procedures this Act provides to that board, or any person alleging such a practice; and (2) the provisions governing the investigation and prosecution of such practice.Requires the President, the Commission, the merit systems protection board, or any person alleging a violation of this Act to report to Congress on such a violation.Authorizes the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) or any other appropriate agency (currently, the Department of Labor) to report to the Commissioner on an employment violation.Amends the Civil Rights Act of 1964 to authorize the Federal Employment Standards Commission to investigate an employment practice without the Commission's approval.Requires the Commission, the Attorney General, the Librarian of Congress, or any person alleging an unlawful employment practice in violation of this Act against an employee or applicant, except as provided in this Act, to report to the appropriate appropriate authorities on such matter.Requires: (1) no person shall discriminate against any individual because such individual has opposed any act or practice made unlawful by this Act or because such person made a charge, testified, assisted, or participated in any manner in an investigation, proceeding, or hearing under this Act.A covered employee is defined in the congressional accountability act of 1995 (Congressional Accountability Act of 1995) and a covered employee (including an applicant) is defined as a person with a prior criminal or civil rights background and is subject to the requirements of such an employee.Sets forth provisions regarding reasonable accommodation and nondue hardship for persons with disabilities.This bill directs the Department of Justice to: (1) make no such state immune from federal or state law enforcement action for a violation of this Act; and (2) make such state law-enforcement action in a Federal or State court of competent jurisdiction for such a violation.
summary: Pregnant Workers Fairness Act  Declares that it is an unlawful employment practice for employers, employment agencies, labor organizations, and other specified entities to: (1) fail to make reasonable accommodations to known limitations related to the pregnancy, childbirth, or related medical conditions of job applicants or employees, unless the accommodation would impose an undue hardship on such an entity's business operation; (2) deny employment opportunities based on the need of the entity to make such reasonable accommodations; (3) require such job applicants or employees to accept an accommodation that they choose not to accept, if such accommodation is unnecessary to perform the job; (4) require such employees to take paid or unpaid leave if another reasonable accommodation can be provided to their known limitations; or (5) take adverse action in terms, conditions, or privileges of employment against an employee requesting or using such reasonable accommodations. Sets forth enforcement procedures and remedies under the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the Congressional Accountability Act of 1995, the Government Employee Rights Act of 1991, and the rights and protections extended to presidential offices. Directs the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission to issue regulations to carry out this Act, including the identification of reasonable accommodations addressing known limitations related to pregnancy, childbirth, or related medical conditions. Prohibits state immunity under the Eleventh Amendment to the Constitution from an action for a violation of this Act.
